Folks, I‚Äôm glad to engage in discussion about this bill and hear critiques. This bill is about protecting YOUR privacy from authoritarian nations and protecting Americans from foreign coercion. I‚Äôm proud of the bipartisan coalition we‚Äôve built to get it done.
TikTok is outright banned in India. It‚Äôs banned on government devices in Canada, the EU, the UK, Norway, New Zealand, and Belgium. We‚Äôre likely to see more countries follow suit soon.
I also want to point out this legislation really isn‚Äôt unusual or overreaching on the global stage ‚Äì plenty of countries have taken even more direct action against TikTok specifically.

We‚Äôre not going to let rail companies just keep putting money in the bank and thinking they can shortchange safety. 

We can‚Äôt shortchange East Palestine. http://pbs.twimg.com/amplify_video_thumb/1641810887366279168/img/3zX7UqWSIXADB7Cg.jpg https://video.twimg.com/amplify_video/1641810887366279168/vid/360x270/4HSU647mpq-p7D3g.mp4?tag=16

But there‚Äôs a reason we‚Äôre all not on MySpace anymore ‚Äì the internet adapts. I have total confidence that there will be apps out there that can facilitate the same communications as TikTok, without being beholden to an authoritarian, communist regime that endangers our security.

MYTH: Senators don‚Äôt understand that people make their living on TikTok!
Fact: I think there‚Äôs a lot of creativity happening on TikTok! I know influencers & other Americans rely on it. I‚Äôm also a former tech entrepreneur, and I wholeheartedly believe in the free marketplace.
This bill takes on big, systemic threats to our national security ‚Äì not individual users.

Let me say it again: there are NO criminal penalties in this bill for your free speech ‚Äì you‚Äôre even free to drag the RESTRICT Act if you want! I stand firmly with freedom of speech, and my bill doesn‚Äôt affect or influence what Americans can say in any way, shape or form.

But it‚Äôs actually even more specific than that. The RESTRICT Act only has the power to mitigate extremely high risk actions ‚Äì like sabotaging U.S. tech, catastrophically impacting infrastructure, or interfering in our federal elections.

The government is only able to review ‚Äúcovered transactions,‚Äù which means transactions involving a foreign adversary (China, Russia, Cuba, Venezuela, North Korea, Iran) or an entity based in those countries.

The RESTRICT Act builds on a process ‚Äì created under President Trump and supported by President Biden ‚Äì that would allow the Secretary of Commerce to review certain transactions. What kind of transactions‚Ä¶?

MYTH: The RESTRICT Act criminalizes what you can say online.
Fact: The RESTRICT Act is focused on foreign corporations, not on users. The 1st Amendment protects Americans‚Äô right to share and receive information ‚Äì and this bill doesn‚Äôt alter that.

I have been incredibly vocal in criticizing U.S. tech companies over the years, and I have written bills that would reign in their bad practices. We absolutely need comprehensive privacy laws in the U.S., and I‚Äôll continue to push for those, too.

A number of Chinese laws require any company under the PRC‚Äôs jurisdiction to assist security services ‚Äì whether that‚Äôs censoring content, sharing private data, or assisting with cyber or transnational repression campaigns against dissidents.

In America, private companies can ‚Äì and often do ‚Äì contest government requests for user data. We‚Äôve got laws on the books and a whole legal system designed to prevent abuses. They‚Äôre imperfect, but we can have a transparent debate about this stuff. That‚Äôs not true in China.

The issue here is that under authoritarian regimes, businesses like TikTok can be FORCED to do the bidding of state intelligence services. While U.S. social media companies need reform, we don‚Äôt require that companies turn over any and all data whenever the government wants.

MYTH: The RESTRICT Act is anti-China xenophobia!
Fact: The RESTRICT Act is aimed at a range of AUTHORITARIAN nations ‚Äì not just China. We need to be clear: our problem is NOT with the Chinese people or Chinese Americans ‚Äì it‚Äôs with the Chinese Communist Party and Xi Jinping.

The RESTRICT Act also prioritizes being candid about these threats with Americans. It requires information about threats to be declassified and shared widely ‚Äì so nothing is being banned or mitigated without clear, transparent reasoning.

A ban is on the table if ‚Äì and only if ‚Äì foreign companies pose a serious threat to our national security. The bill also allows for less drastic remedies if a full ban isn‚Äôt required ‚Äì think privacy or corporate transparency requirements.

MYTH: The RESTRICT Act unfairly targets TikTok!
Fact: It would be unconstitutional to ban a specific company just because lawmakers feel like it. The RESTRICT Act is a framework to identify and study ALL foreign tech threats where a serious national security risk is presented.
The bill is restricted to tech from just a handful of nations ‚Äì China, Russia, Cuba, Venezuela, North Korea, and Iran ‚Äì that are controlled by authoritarian regimes.

MYTH: This bill allows unlimited surveillance by the U.S. government!
Fact: Totally untrue. This bill doesn‚Äôt give the government any power to track what you‚Äôre searching! In fact, it is aimed at COUNTERING foreign surveillance from authoritarian nations.

A strong labor movement is critical to the industrial policy required to rebuild and revitalize communities devastated by offshoring and bad trade deals. This will create thousands of good paying union jobs. 

https://www.foreignaffairs.com/china/ro-khanna-new-industrial-age-america-manufacturing-superpower

I don‚Äôt just talk about the importance of unions. In 2022, my office became the second in Congress to unionize. I hope this will become a new norm in Congress. 

https://www.commondreams.org/news/2022/09/30/incredible-omar-and-khanna-staffers-join-levins-office-unionizing

In 1935, FDR passed the Wagner Act, guaranteeing the right of private sector employees to organize into unions, engage in collective bargaining, and strike. I co-sponsored the PRO Act and called for more NLRB funding because all workers deserve that same right today.

Over the past few years, we have seen an encouraging surge in union drives and earlier this month, the historic end of a right to work law in Michigan. But as Amazon and Starbucks have demonstrated, workers still face many obstacles to unionizing. 

https://apnews.com/article/right-to-work-repeal-michigan-democrats-b4304a2780909d37e76f211c7b070a6b

Despite what Starbucks CEO Howard Schultz would have us believe, American workers cannot count on billionaire CEOs to look out for their interests, no matter how fervently Howard Schultz believes in his own altruism. They need the right to unionize.

We can‚Äôt have economic justice without strong unions and strong labor laws. Workers should not face the threat of losing their jobs or having their workplaces shuttered because they choose to unionize.

It is up to progressives to build a strong labor movement that can not only fight for the interests of working people, but also serve as a necessary check on corporate power. Collective bargaining must be part of the social contract.

The problem is bigger than Howard Schultz. Right to work laws and the decimation of organized labor since the 1980s have left American workers without a means of leveraging their power for better wages and protections.

Even worse, Starbucks has successfully obtained the legal authority to spy on workers, sifting through private communications to find and fire anyone who sympathizes with unionizing. Could it get any more dystopian? 

https://jacobin.com/2023/03/starbucks-union-busting-retaliation-employee-surveillance

A March ruling held that Starbucks violated labor laws to deter union organizing in Buffalo. Howard Schultz could make things right by rehiring staff at that location. Instead, Starbucks is going to court to make sure workers don‚Äôt get their jobs back.

https://www.cbsnews.com/amp/news/starbucks-violated-worker-rights-union-fight-labor-judge/

Starbucks drew more than 80 unfair labor practice charges from the NLRB over the past 18 months, more than any other company. Is this what Howard Schultz meant when he said he ‚Äúhad conversations that could‚Äôve been interpreted differently than intended?‚Äù 

https://twitter.com/moreperfectus/status/1641097451921629186?s=46&t=BRIC5s_pk7HFEQm-toiPuA QT @MorePerfectUS Bernie Sanders to Howard Schultz: "Have you ever threatened, coerced, or intimidated a worker for supporting a union?"

Schultz won't answer no. "I've had conversations that could‚Äôve been interpreted in a different way than I intended..." http://pbs.twimg.com/amplify_video_thumb/1641096895714951171/img/fkh7es24FKRYWDwu.jpg https://video.twimg.com/amplify_video/1641096895714951171/vid/432x270/2xneDtWxaDI1i9Kw.mp4?tag=16

Despite Howard Schultz‚Äôs efforts, Starbucks workers at nearly 300 stores have voted to join Starbucks Workers United. Under threat of subpoena by HELP chair @BernieSanders, Schultz tried and failed to justify his union-busting. 

https://twitter.com/i/broadcasts/1ynJOaoYXjXKR?t=7

In yesterday‚Äôs hearing, Howard Schultz showed that our concerns were more than justified.
